text.front:
LONG-TIME PHOTOLUMINESCENCE KINETICS IN QUANTUM
DOTS
K. Kr√°l *
Institute of Physics, Academy of Sciences of Czech Republic, v.v.i., Na Slovance 2, 18221 Prague 8
Czech Republic
text.p:
One of the remarkable experimental characteristics of the so called blinking of the quantum dots is
their power law distribution of the lengths of the on (off) periods during which the photoluminescence is on
(off). The power law time characteristics do not seem to be rare in the zero-dimensional systems. In the present
theoretical work we want to pay attention to still another significant effect, namely to the experimentally
observed power-law time-dependence of the decay of photoluminescence of a quantum dot sample after
excitation by a laser pulse. The luminescence response of certain quantum dot systems to a short laser pulse has
been experimentally found to be a slow process, developing in time as a power-law dependence, in contrast to
the perhaps usually expected exponential decay. We bring arguments in favor of the interpretation that the
power-law decay can be basically a single-dot property connected closely to the electron-LO-phonon
interaction. This interaction is included in a degree expressing a non-adiabatic influence of the atomic lattice
motion on the electrons inside the quantum dot. The properties of the system are analyzed numerically and
compared to experiments.
